title-group.article-title: Assessing stressor exposure, chemsex use, and adjustment disorder in a sample of men who have sex with men

trans-title-group.trans-title: Evaluación de la exposición a estresores, el consumo de chemsex y trastorno de adaptación en una muestra de hombres que tienen relaciones sexuales con hombres

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Background: Evidence suggests that men who have sex with men (MSM) experience heightened risk for stressor-related mental health issues. This may be exacerbated among those who engage in chemsex; recreational substance use during sex. Valid assessment of adjustment difficulties, and risk factors associated with these, is needed to better understand these wellbeing risks. The present study aimed to validate a novel screening tool for Adjustment Disorder (AjD) in this population.

Method: A sample of MSM (N = 503) completed an online survey of stressful life experiences. Among those who reported exposure to a stressor (n = 376), the factorial structure of the International Adjustment Disorder Questionnaire (IADQ) was assessed using Confirmatory Factor Analysis. Probable diagnostic status was assessed using established criteria. Associations with stressor exposure and chemsex participation were examined using between-group comparisons.

Results: A unidimensional model representing a single latent AjD factor best fit these data. AjD symptomatology was commonly reported, with screening results indicating that 36.44% of participants met criteria for a probable AjD diagnosis. Small effect sizes were found for associations between positive AjD screening status, chemsex participation, and a range of stressors including problems related to health, relationships, finances, work, and housing. A medium effect size was found for the association between multiple stressor exposure and probable AjD diagnosis.

Conclusions: Findings support the use of the IADQ as a brief and valid measure of AjD among men who have sex with men. Various stressful life experiences and chemsex participation may constitute risk factors for AjD, with exposure to multiple stressor types representing a particularly salient risk factor. Screening for stressful life experiences, chemsex practice, and AjD may identify those at risk for adverse health and wellbeing outcomes in this population.

list-item.p: The International Adjustment Disorder Questionnaire (IADQ) is supported as a screening tool among men who have sex with men.
Multiple stressor exposure and chemsex participation may be risk factors for Adjustment Disorder (AjD).
Screening for AjD may identify those at risk for stressor- and chemsex-related (mental) health outcomes.

trans-abstract.p: Antecedentes: La evidencia sugiere que hombres que tienen sexo con hombre (MSM, por sus siglas en inglés) experimentan un mayor riesgo de padecer problemas de salud mental relacionado con estresores. Esto puede verse exacerbado entre quienes practican chemsex; consumo recreacional de sustancias durante las relaciones sexuales. Se necesita una evaluación válida de las dificultades de adaptación y factores de riesgo asociados para comprender mejor estos riesgos para el bienestar. El presente estudio tuvo como objetivo validar una nueva herramienta de detección del trastorno adaptativo (AjD, por sus siglas en inglés) en esta población.

Método: Una muestra de MSN (N = 503) completó una encuesta en línea de experiencias vitales estresantes. Entre quienes reportaron exposición a un estresor (n = 376), se evaluó la estructura factorial del Cuestionario Internacional del Trastorno Adaptativo (IADQ, por sus siglas en inglés) mediante Análisis Factorial Confirmatorio. El probable estado diagnostico se evaluó utilizando criterios establecidos. Se examinaron las asociaciones con exposición a estresores y participación en chemsex utilizando comparaciones intergrupales.

Resultados: Un modelo unidimensional que representa un único factor latente de AjD se ajusto mejor a estos datos. La sintomatología AjD fue frecuente, y los resultados de tamizaje indicaron que un 36,44% de los participantes cumplían los criterios para un probable diagnóstico de AjD. Se observaron tamaños del efecto bajo para las asociaciones entre el resultado positivo en el tamizaje AjD, la participación en chemsex y diversos factores estresantes, como problemas de salud, relaciones, finanzas, trabajo y vivienda. Se observó un tamaño de efecto medio para la asociación entre la exposición a múltiples factores estresantes y el diagnóstico probable de AjD.

Conclusiones: Los hallazgos respaldan el uso del IADQ como una medida breve y valida para el AjD en hombres que tienen sexo con hombres. Diversas experiencias vitales estresantes y la participación en chemsex pueden constituir factores de riesgo para la AjD, siendo la exposición a múltiples tipos de estresores un factor de riesgo particularmente relevante. El tamizaje de experiencias vitales estresantes, la práctica de chemsex y la AjD puede identificar a quienes presentan riesgo de sufrir consecuencias adversas para la salud y el bienestar en esta población.

kwd-group.title: KEYWORDS
kwd-group.kwd: men who have sex with men

kwd-group.title: PALABRAS CLAVE
kwd-group.kwd: hombres que tienen sexo con hombres

funding-group.funding-statement: This work was supported by Queen’s University Belfast [581296438].

sec.title: Adjustment disorder
sec.p: Adjustment Disorder (AjD) is defined as a maladaptive response to a identifiable psychosocial stressor or stressors, characterised by symptoms of Preoccupation and Failure to Adapt (WHO, 2019). AjD is highlighted as a globally relevant condition and is frequently used by practitioners (Evans et al., 2013). The latest International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11) adopts a novel approach in framing AjD as a distinct diagnostic entity with a clearly defined symptom profile (Bachem & Casey, 2018). Notably, the ICD-11 emphasises preoccupation with the stressor, manifesting as excessive worry, rumination, or recurrent and distressing thoughts, as a core feature, offering a more precise and operationalisable framework for assessing of AjD pathology (WHO, 2019).

Historically, critics have argued the imprecision of AjD diagnostics contributed to its status as a catch-all category capturing general distress. However, such criticisms have waned with the introduction of more rigorous diagnostic guidelines (Bachem & Casey, 2018; Zapata-Ospina et al., 2024). The revision to AjD in the ICD-11 is notably informed by empirical and clinical evidence (Glaesmer et al., 2015; Kazlauskas et al., 2017), and is accompanied by the introduction of the International Adjustment Disorder Questionnaire (IADQ); a measure offering assessment of diagnostic requirements in line with the ICD-11 (Shevlin et al., 2020). The psychometric properties of this measure have been assessed considering the validity of a one-factor model, indicative of global AjD, and two-factor model, representing Preoccupation and Failure to Adapt domains (Jannini et al., 2023; Levin et al., 2022; Shevlin et al., 2020). This previous evidence has supported the simultaneous acceptability of both models in community samples; the current study proposes to extend this assessment contributing validation of this scale in a novel population potentially at elevated risk for stressor exposure and adjustment difficulties.

Prior evidence has highlighted AjD as a prevalent concern as more than 50% of clinicians report using this classification at least weekly in their practice (Reed et al., 2011), however, the specific diagnostic criteria offered by the ICD-11 and validated measures of this construct offer opportunity for more precise estimation of AjD difficulties (Shevlin et al., 2020). Estimated prevalence of ICD-11 AjD difficulties in general population samples ranges from 15.6% to 35.8% (Jannini et al., 2023; Shevlin et al., 2020). Relative risk for stressor exposure and stressor-related disorders may be of particular concern for the Men who have Sex with Men (MSM) community, potentially experiencing greater risk for psychosocial stressors and compounded effects on mental health due to their minority group status (Hickson et al., 2016; Sun et al., 2020). The current study aims to address in part the distinct lack of evidence assessing AjD difficulties in the MSM community.

sec.title: Mental health risk in the MSM community
sec.p: The MSM community may be considered at elevated risk for psychosocial stressors and poor mental health relative to heterosexual men (Hickson et al., 2016). These include stress associated with feared stigma, minority status, and (sexual) health concerns (Batchelder et al., 2017; Sun et al., 2020). This group is evidenced to be at risk for poorer sexual health, substance misuse, and adverse mental health outcomes (King et al., 2008; Sun et al., 2020; Voisin et al., 2017). Notably previous investigation of MSM residing in the UK has suggested this group to report significantly greater depression symptomatology relative to the general population (Miltz et al., 2017).

This risk may be understood through Minority Stress theory which proposes that minority groups experience increased risk for wellbeing problems due to stigma, discrimination, and prejudice (Meyer, 2003). This theoretical perspective has been applied previously to the study of mental health outcomes among MSM due to potential exposure to stressors related to minority sexuality status (Sun et al., 2020). Additionally, a salient concern for adverse mental health outcomes in this group is the use of chemsex; recreational drug use (e.g. methamphetamine, mephedrone, GHB/GBL, and/or ketamine) in a sexual setting to enhance sexual pleasure and performance (Macfarlane, 2016). This practice has been identified as a public health concern for this community with MSM engaged in chemsex considered at risk for sexual risk taking behaviours, addiction, sexually transmitted infection, and medical complications (Glynn et al., 2018; Macfarlane, 2016). Evidence also suggests that the MSM group taking part in chemsex activities may be at particularly heightened risk for stressful life experiences and adverse mental health outcomes (Bohn et al., 2020).

Substances commonly associated with chemsex may be of particular concern in to the context of stressor exposure and mental health difficulties. For instance, methamphetamine use has been positively associated with AjD presentation (Yen & Chong, 2006). The association between AjD and substance misuse is hypothesised to be underpinned by a desire to relieve these symptoms; however, the misuse of substances associated with depressive effects may exacerbate or conflate symptoms (Casey, 2009). Indeed, methamphetamine use within chemsex contexts has been found to contribute to depression symptomatology (Schecke et al., 2019). This highlights the potential for a cyclical and interrelated risk dynamic, stressor exposure, adverse mental health outcomes, and substance misuse that mutually reinforce one another (Castellana et al., 2025). There is, however, limited evidence relating to contemporary assessment of stressor-related difficulties among LGBT+ communities, with prior evidence primarily focusing on trauma experiences and traumatic stress (Charak et al., 2023). Nevertheless, there is growing recognition of a distinct pathology associated with experience of non-traumatic life stressors and adjustment difficulties that warrants consideration in assessment (Bachem & Casey, 2018).

Those in the MSM community may considered at increased risk for a range of psychosocial stressors not necessarily indicative of potentially traumatic events, but which may confer risk for AjD difficulties (Sun et al., 2020). Indeed, previous meta-analysis has indicated that relative risk for mental health issues is elevated among people with non-heterosexual identities, and that reporting of stressor-related issues is greater than that for mood or anxiety disorders (Barr et al., 2022). For this reason the importance of AjD consideration and assessment is highlighted; recognising the role of environmental stressors in psychopathology presentations (Zapata-Ospina et al., 2024). There is hence an evidenced need to assesses exposure to psychosocial stressors and distress in this group which may be at disproportionate risk AjD difficulties.

sec.title: Current study
sec.p: The current investigation thus aims to contribute to the ongoing work validating the IADQ as an assessment of ICD-11 AjD through investigation of psychometric properties in a novel sample potentially at risk for stressor-related difficulties: MSM involved in chemsex. Additionally, this study aims to contribute to understanding of stressor-related difficulties in a sample of MSM involved in chemsex through evaluation of the association between stressor exposure, chemsex participation, and AjD.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Adjustment Disorder Symptomatology was assessed using the IADQ (Shevlin et al., 2020). The IADQ assesses AjD in line with ICD-11 criteria: recording current experience of stressor exposure with dichotomous responses (nine items), and six items assessing symptoms of Preoccupation and Failure to Adapt rated on a scale from 0 ‘Not at all’ to 4 ‘Extremely’. Scoring probable diagnosis using this measure in line with ICD-11 diagnostic criteria suggests respondents must endorse distress (responding ‘Moderately’ or ≥ 2) related at least one symptom of Preoccupation, one Failure to Adapt symptom, significant functional impairment related to these, and confirm difficulties arising within one month following stress exposure (Shevlin et al., 2020).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Respondents were surveyed through an online panel (Prolific) in July 2024 selecting for men who identified as homosexual or bisexual during registration, and had some awareness of the concept of chemsex. Panel members were adults aged 18+, resident in the US or UK. All participants (N = 503) were presented with the IADQ current stressor screening questions, and if they endorsed exposure to one or more stressors were presented with symptom questions (n = 376, 74.75%). Chi-square comparisons suggested that, compared to those who did not report current stressor exposure, those in the analysis subsample were less likely to report being partnered (p = .020) and generally more likely to report more frequent chemsex participation in the previous 6 months (p = .029). No other significant differences were observed in demographic characteristics between the total and study subsample (see Supplementary File 1 available via the OSF page for this project: osf.io/7sgny/).

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p:
Data for those who responded to the IADQ were analysed using Confirmatory Factor Analysis assessing one- and two- latent factor structures of this measure in line with previous studies (Jannini et al., 2023; Shevlin et al., 2020). Robust Maximum Likelihood (MLR) and Weighted Least Square Mean and Variance (WLSMV) estimation were used for 5-point and binary response data respectively to identify the model providing the best fit for these data, see Figure 1. In line with best practices for factor analysis, a range of fit indices were computed to aid model comparison and selection applying established guidelines to facilitate interpretation of acceptable fit: Comparative Fit Index (CFI) and Tucker Lewis Index (TLI) results ≥ .95, Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) and Standardised Root Mean Square of Approximation (SRMR) < .08 (Hu & Bentler, 1999). The Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) and Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) provided metrics of absolute fit for the MLR models with lower values indicative of superior model fit (Brown & Moore, 2012). Figure 1.
Graphical representation of estimated international adjustment disorder questionnaire factor models.

Probable diagnosis of AjD based on ICD-11 criteria was also estimated in this sample, and contrasts evaluated between probable diagnostic groups on stressor endorsement using Chi-square and Welch’s t-test. Effect sizes were calculated for these statistical tests, Cramer’s V and Cohen’s d respectively, to aid comparison. These measures provide indication of the strength of association between variables with values indicative of a small effect [d = 0.20, V = .10], a medium effect [d = 0.50, V = .30], or a large effect [d > 0.80, V > .50] (Cohen, 1988). All analyses were performed using R Studio version 2023.06.0, Build 421 (R Studio Team, 2023), and syntax for these detailed in Supplementary File 1.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The current study sample was comprised entirely of cis-gendered males aged between 18 and 78 (M = 38.53, SD = 12.89). The majority identified as bisexual (63.22%), partnered or in a relationship (52.09%), having completed university or postgraduate education (84.10%), and identified ethnically as White (45.27%) or Black (40.24%). Detailed summary of participant characteristics is provided in Supplementary File 1.

sec.title: Stressor endorsement and IADQ psychometric properties
sec.p:
Endorsement of current stressors experienced is presented in Table 1. In the total sample the most frequently endorsed current stressors were; Personal health problems (40.60%), Financial problems (37.25%), and Relationship problems (34.00%). Participants reported a mean of 1.81 categories of current stressor experience (SD = 1.64); n = 376 (74.75%) endorsed experience of at least one stressor type and completed the symptom endorsement items of the IADQ. Table 1.
Stressor endorsement for total study sample.

n (%).b
Mean (SD).

The most frequently endorsed IADQ symptoms were ‘I worry a lot more since the stressful event(s)’ (67.29%, M = 2.05, SD = 1.03) and ‘I often feel afraid about what might happen in the future since the stressful event(s)’ (67.29%, M = 2.04, SD = 1.11). Detailed reporting of item endorsement and correlations is provided in Supplementary File 1. All IADQ item responses were positively corelated (Spearman’s ρ = .54 – .78), and internal reliability for the unidimensional model was found to be excellent (Cronbach’s α = .91).

Results of factor analysis indicated favourable fit indices for the unidimensional factor model in line with standardised interpretation, and suggested this model to provide the best fit to these data using both MLR and WLSMV estimators (see Table 2). All IADQ items displayed favourable factor loadings (Range: 0.714–0.868) suggesting these items to robustly indicate the identified single latent factor. Table 2.
Fit indices for international adjustment disorder questionnaire factor models.

sec.title: Probable diagnosis and associations
sec.p: Algorithmic scoring was applied in line with diagnostic guidelines to estimate probable AjD diagnosis (see Supplemental File 1). The majority of the stressor-reporting sample met criteria for the Preoccupation (80.32%) and Failure to Adapt (71.54%) domains, and endorsed functional impairment related to these (66.76%). Comparatively fewer met diagnostic criteria of having these difficulties present within one month following stressor exposure (57.18%). Applying full screening criteria necessitating all these are endorsed, n = 137 (36.44%) of the IADQ respondent sample met criteria for probable diagnosis of AjD.

Probable diagnostic category was subsequently compared with respect to stressor endorsements and chemsex participation (see Table 3, Supplemental File 1). Significant between-groups differences were observed suggesting those in the positive screening group more likely to report: Financial Problems (χ²(1) = 12.86, p < .001, Cramer’s V = 0.19), Work Problems (χ²(1) = 5.76, p = .016, Cramer’s V = 0.12), Housing Problems (χ²(1) = 7.48, p = .006, Cramer’s V = 0.14), Relationship Problems (χ²(1) = 9.20, p = .002, Cramer’s V = 0.16), and Personal Health Problems (χ²(1) = 12.21, p < .001, Cramer’s V = 0.18). The association between these individual stressor experiences and positive screening for AjD difficulties may be interpreted as small effects (Cohen, 1988). Table 3.

Exposure to multiple stressor types was found to have a medium effect size association with AjD difficulties, with those in the positive AjD screening group reporting exposure to more types of stressor (Welch's t(254.6) = 5.16, p < .001, Cohen’s d = 0.57). Results of the comparison of chemsex participation between diagnostic groups suggested the positive AjD screening group reported more frequent chemsex participation, and this effect size was interpreted as small (χ²(4) = 27.07, p < .001, Cramer’s V = 0.27).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study sought to contribute to validation of the IADQ, and assess associations between probable diagnostic status, stressor experiences, and chemsex use in a MSM sample. Results suggested the IADQ to robustly assess a unified latent factor indicative of AjD-related distress, and that symptomatology was reported by a majority of study participants. The ultimate conclusion that a univariate factor model provided the best fit for these data contrast that of previous research validating the factor structure of the IADQ (Jannini et al., 2023; Levin et al., 2022; Shevlin et al., 2020). In those previous investigations the Preoccupation and Failure to Adapt domains have, however, been noted to be highly correlated, and the relatively close fit of these models argued to evidence the viability of a univariate concept of AjD (Lorenz et al., 2018; Shevlin et al., 2020).

Screening of diagnostic requirements suggested that 36.44% of IADQ respondents in this sample screened positive for probable AjD, highlighting this as a potential concern for this group. It should be noted that identified problems associated with elevated risk for probable AjD were widely endorsed by respondents highlighting the relevance of effective screening of stressor and adjustment difficulties for this group to effectively identify those potentially in need of support. Additionally, aspects of AjD symptomatology were reported by the majority of this study sample, suggesting that subclinical Preoccupation and Failure to Adapt difficulties may be prevalent in this group. These findings evidence that AjD difficulties are a significant concern for this MSM group, and suggest the need to robustly screen for stressful life experiences and stressor-related mental health difficulties in research and practice.

Between-groups comparison suggested a range of individual stressors, and the cumulative burden of stressors, to be significant risk factors for AjD in this sample. Likewise, the frequency of engaging in chemsex was positively associated with stressor exposure and positive screening for AjD. The relevance of those difficulties highlighted previously of particular concern for the MSM group (Batchelder et al., 2017; Sun et al., 2020) are emphasised in light of findings from this study. Stressors associated with probable AjD diagnosis included Financial, Work, and Housing problems. These problems may be considered near universal stressors, and their effect on wellbeing understood through the Conservation of Resources Theory whereby the objective or threatened loss of resources may exacerbate the influence of stressors and adversely impact health (Hobfoll, 2011). In the context of the current study, interpersonal and financial resource-related stressors being significantly associated with AjD difficulties suggests that these stressors warrant screening in the assessment of mental health and related risk factors.

The current study findings also suggested that experience of Loved One’s Health Problems was not significantly associated with AjD, however, personal health problems were. The relative severity and distress of stressor exposure may be considered; as health problems affecting oneself may be perceived as more severe and distressing, constituting greater risk for AjD. Previous evidence has suggested that life-threatening health problems are associated with increased risk for stressor-related disorders (Geoffrion et al., 2022). Notably, however, the assessment of health problems as psychosocial stressor(s) related to ICD-11 AjD diagnostic guidelines and IADQ administration do not specify these are required to be ‘life threatening’ and these may instead constitute a potentially traumatic event (Geoffrion et al., 2022). Future investigations may consider including detailed qualitative assessment of stressor experiences and appraisals to better understand the qualities of these as risk factors for AjD and other stressor-related disorders.

The theoretical perspective of Minority Stress may be used to understand the role of Relationship- and Personal health- problems in the context of the study sample; highlighting minority sexuality identity as a moderating factor that may exacerbate stressor-related issues through stigma and discrimination appraisals (Sun et al., 2020). One potential salient consideration is that of HIV-related stigma that may exist for this group. Previous research has likewise highlighted sexual health concerns as a potential stressor for the MSM community, both in terms of concern for one’s personal health and the perceived stigma of health protective practices such as taking Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (Batchelder et al., 2017). Given concerns about one’s personal health problems was identified as a significant risk factor for AjD in this sample, addressing personal health concerns of particular importance for the MSM community may be a viable strategy to mitigate AjD risk among those engaged in risky sexual behaviours or seeking help for sexual health concerns.

Likewise considered is the role of multiple stressor exposure identified as a salient predictor of AjD. Previous research has indicated that cumulative exposure to traumatic stress is associated with heightened risk for PTSD outcomes among LGBTQ + identifying individuals (Charak et al., 2023). Minority Stress theory posits that individuals’ membership may result in compounded experience of stress and adversity related to minority identity (Sun et al., 2020). It is also considered that some stressors may limit available resources and coping strategies thus exacerbating the risk for adverse outcomes following subsequent stressor exposure (Hobfoll, 2011). The consistency in findings related to traumatic stress and adjustment difficulties associated with multiple stressor exposure highlights the potential value in broad assessment of stressor exposure and reactions specific to the MSM group in research and clinical practice.

Current chemsex use was also significantly associated with stressor exposure and with AjD difficulties in this sample. Mental health difficulties are associated with increased risk for adverse sexual health outcomes through increase sexual risk-taking behaviour (Miltz et al., 2017). This may be understood also through Minority Stress theory, whereby recreational substance use may be used as a maladaptive coping strategy in dealing with sexual and gender minority associated stress (Parent et al., 2019). Indeed, comorbid AjD and substance misuse are associated with an increased risk of suicidality (Castellana et al., 2025). This recreational substance misuse has been associated with adverse health and wellbeing outcomes through biological sequala of substance misuse, and adverse impacts on one’s finances and work due to adverse mental health outcomes (Bohn et al., 2020; Macfarlane, 2016). Assessment of AjD and chemsex in the MSM group is hence emphasised as this may intersect with other risk factors for AjD, and be used effectively to mitigate adverse health outcomes.

The assessment tools used should also be considered as the definition and categorisation of AjD difficulties remain subject to interpretation. Qualitative investigation of individual narratives of their stressor experiences and adjustment difficulties has highlighted the diversity of Preoccupation and Failure to Adapt domains as experienced by individuals which are reminiscent of those difficulties captured by the IADQ, and also include expanded reports of appetite, sleep, and interpersonal issues (Vancappel et al., 2024). Additionally, previous investigations have highlighted tendency of clinicians towards diagnosis of affective disorders, failing to attribute psychological distress to stressor exposure (Zapata-Ospina et al., 2024). There thus remains a need to assess the potential diversity of stressor exposure and symptom-related difficulties in mental health assessment for the MSM group.

sec.title: Strength & limitations
sec.p: The potential limitation of self-report measurement used in the current study should be considered; this method of assessment may be prone to reporting biases and may be supplemented by clinician assessment. Nevertheless, the use of standardised assessment and the application of psychometrically validated models of the IADQ in this study represent methodological strengths. Diagnostic exclusions exist suggesting that AjD diagnosis may not be received when difficulties are conflated with another diagnosis such as Prolonged Grief Disorder, Depressive disorders, and Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (WHO, 2019). Previous evidence has shown that incorporation of such exclusion criteria may significantly reduce the estimated prevalence of AjD (Shevlin et al., 2020); as these findings report the screening prevalence of AjD without the application of exclusion criteria interpretation and generalisation of estimated prevalence should be made cautiously.

The current study contributes to the literature by assessing AjDin a novel sample, thereby enhancing our understanding of this disorder in diverse populations. However, these results should be interpreted in light of the US and UK populations surveyed. A notable limitation of this study, and of the wider literature concerning stressor-related disorders, is the sparse inclusion of groups from non-WEIRD [Western, Educated, Industrialised, Rich, and Democratic] contexts (Maercker, 2022). As assessment of AjD and stressor-related disorders is a globally relevant concern (Evans et al., 2013) future research should seek to extend this validation to wider contexts.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: These results concur with those of previous work suggesting the value of the IADQ as a brief and psychometrically valid measure of ICD-11 AjD, and extend this evidence through its application to a novel population. In this MSM sample, a range of stressful life experiences emerged as potential risk factors for AjD, with exposure to multiple stressor categories appearing particularly salient. Future research and clinical practice should consider routine screening for these difficulties within the MSM community, particularly among individuals engaged in chemsex practices.

sec.title: Disclosure statement
sec.p: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: Data supporting the findings of this work are made available via an Open Science Framework project page [https://osf.io/rw4ja/]. For supplementary material accompanying this paper see the associated Open Science Framework project [https://osf.io/7sgny/].

sec.title: Supplemental Material
sec.p: Supplemental data for this article can be accessed online at https://doi.org/10.1080/20008066.2025.2519857.
